text:
I'm still trying to get the hang of things with CVS. The attached DIFF is unified, and should be what 
we need to fix. Hopefully, we can use this to help me better get up to speed with using CVS.

Web Maestro Clay
creator: the.webmaestro@gmail.com
the.webmaestro@gmail.com
text:
Created attachment 8571
Before/after diff -u of compiling.xml

Created attachment 8572
Modified compiling.xml file (in case DIFF has problems)
creator: the.webmaestro@gmail.com
the.webmaestro@gmail.com
text:
I've also attached compiling.xml, in case there are problems with my diff file. Don't worry, if all 
goes well with my diff, I won't make a habit of including the whole XML file every time! ;-p

I have committed most of this patch. Two comments:

1. I did not add the <note> re: using ./build.sh instead of build.sh in some 
environments. IMO, this is really a dangerous precedent. If we document this, 
then we probably need to document chown and chmod in case they don't have their 
ownership and permissions set properly, and we may need to help them get 
network issues resolved if the script resides on a remote filesystem, etc. 
There really is no end to the amount of helpful information we can add that 
only has the effect of making it difficult to find the FOP information that we 
are *really* trying to provide. If you disagree, please raise the issue on fop-
dev, and we'll see if we can come to an agreement.

2. The patch that you submitted did not have either DOS or Unix line-endings 
and my fancy editor did not recognize Mac line-endings either. I used the full 
file that you submitted to get the patch done. In this case, that was no 
problem, but in other cases it would make the job undoable. Open the file in vi 
to make sure that it is correct. (Instead of using your local file, download it 
from this bug -- it is possible that Bugzilla has converted something).

Thank you *very* much for the patch, and for your efforts in general toward 
making the doc better.
creator: vic@outfitr.com
the.webmaestro@gmail.com
text:
I agree about the ./build.sh comment. 'Nuff said.

As for the line endings, the reason it didn't work, was because I copied the text from my Terminal 
(via the clipboard), and pasted it in a UNICODE text file (FWIW, I don't know if it uses Unix, DOS, or 
Mac line endings--my guess is that it uses "UNICODE" ones). Anyway, that was silly! I should've 
just >'d it to a txt file. D'oh! Anyway, I look forward to continuing on this path.

Web Maestro Clay
batch transition pre-FOP1.0 resolved+fixed bugs to closed+fixed
creator: gadams@apache.org
